name: Selective Adaptation v.1.1
description:
This deck's economy is built around Magnum Opus. If you do not draw it or either SMC or Test Run you should mulligan (judgement call depending on the 5 cards in your initial draw).

Replicator helps thin out your deck and get hardware out quick. You only want to install 2 (toss the 3rd).

Darwin is your main breaker. Ideally you will have it hosted on Omni-Drive to feed it at the start of your turn.

Sneakedoor and Nerve Agent are made to surprise the Corp if you can bottle up their remotes. You will probably know they have agendas in hand if they clear virus tokens.

name: For science. You monster.
description:
Love kills slowly.

  • Only Ice up HQ and R&D, play all Agendas and Assets as they come.
  • Advice: Keep some cash. Don't get siphoned too often, but recovering by Gila Hands or Profiteering (take all creds, f#% Bad Pub) is easy.

Ratio: 3 (3 Flatline, 0 Agendas) : 0 (0/0 An, 0/1 Sh, 0/2 Cr)

name: Theo, caretaker to one damaged girl..
description:
Stimhack away to a big rig. Brain damage? Meh..

"Whateva! My scary Uncle Theophilius looks after me. He even has two bodyguards to protect him when he sells stims on street corners. I do what I want!"

name: Jinteki Burn
description:
This deck is centered around taxing the runner's grip and using a constant flat-line threat to slow the runner while agendas are scored. Using Jinteki: Personal Evolution means that the runner must always have a card in hand to score an agenda, which combos well with Komainu. A great first turn play is Komainu, agenda, Hedge Fund. If they run, they will lose their hand and then have to jack out because a stolen agenda would end the game. If they don't run, you can quickly score the agenda. This combination is so mean that you'll find that once they know you can do this they might not run, allowing you to bluff with another ICE.

Neural EMP and Punitive Counterstrike raise the threshold for a safe run for the runner; e.g. if you have Punitive Counterstrike in hand, they must have at least 4 cards in hand between running and the end of the turn to safely steal The Future Perfect. Fetal AI is even tougher to steal. Cerebral Cast can lead to Scorched Earth unless they are willing to take a brain damage, which would make the flat-line threat greater.

The ICE in the deck is mainly economical, taxing type ice that will cost the runner even if they have the right icebreaker. Sure, they can pay clicks or credits to get through, but do they have enough cards to survive Fetal AI or Project Junebug backed up with kill cards on the following Corp turn?

Like other Jinteki decks, this deck is very strong against criminal or basically any fast runner deck with a poor late game. Shock! and Snare! with all of the damage cards shut down decks that need to hit central servers hard. The deck does lose some strength in the late game because it does not have any recurring economy. These were removed from earlier versions because they were easy targets for the runner with no hard-ETR ICE.

Enjoy! Thanks for any comments.

name: RFC: Tower to the Sky
description:
Prototype Always Advance (AA) deck. The plan is to pump up Plan Bs and ICE like Ice Wall and Swarm with Matrix Analyzer. Keep it all down to two remote servers, and pile the ICE on them. Spend at least one click every turn advancing something.

Comments welcome.

name: Punitive Grid
description:
First time making a deck with an ID that's yet to be released but here goes:

Big ICE like Curtain Wall winds up being your econ with Oversight AI if you want it to be. Just build econ with a glacier type of archetype in front of your main servers and bring back those oversights to pump massive stuff.

Install an Off the Grid and start your advancing agendas. If you happen to get a 5/3 stolen, just use Punitive Counterstrike with some help from the Blue Sun's ability to boost the trace.

name: RR - Caissa
description: First draft of a Caissa-themed deck, trying out Escher to synergize with one or more of said Caissa.

name: Veggie Tales
description: fast track for atlas then play the aggsec woo woo

name: Jinteki big decision rush
description:
Cerebral overwriter or even just junebug could be the trap? maybe.

Hive is super taxing, 1 research is just a fourth econ for turn 1, you dont want to give them money often. Maybe 2 shi kyu could be fine. Fast track then mushin will probably be your turn once every game. Try not to play vs. silhouette ok

name: That is just painful to watch
Kill Bill (vol 3)
description:
This is a PE kill deck I've been experimenting with that has had some good results. I'll be tweaking it for sure and appreciate feedback. It's inspired by my new favorite agenda—House of Knives. It brought me back to PE Jinteki.

The goal is to score House of Knives as soon as possible. When that's scored it is just about getting/making the opportunity to flatline the runner. This is hard of course, but even if I don't get the chance, having it on the table normally slows a runner enough to give me the chance to score agendas for the win. The Snares! and Shocks will also slow them down as they re-fill their hand.

Caprice is there to help in the remotes to try to score in those moments when the flatline is unlikely. The one Cerebral is there mostly as a bluff so I can install, advance, advance and scare the runner. Even if it is trashed they don't know I'm running only one copy.

Normally I put Hokusai Grids in the central servers, wherever they are more likely to run, it will definitely give runners a difficult decision if house of knives is scored.

The best way to make the flatline happen is to corporate troubleshoot a Komainu or lay down a Inazuma into Komainu. Corporate trouble shooting Inazuma is also an option. These normally go in a central, but if scoring out of remotes is necessary because a House of Knives wasn't scored, that can work.

It's a fun little combo to pull off.

"And then at that point Billy, your house started to shake, the heavens opened up ..." (Favorite quote from The Rock)

This wipes the hand out leaving the rest for House of Knives or Emp.

Throwing in two shocks and a Fetal AI makes Susanoo dangerous and potentially a way to flatline in archives.

Private Contracts are there to recover from the Account Siphons, a weakness with my porous ice. The other weakness is Parasite recursion, but thankfully you aren't too worried about shutting them out.

It has been fun to play and I'll be tweaking it for some time to see if my flatline percentage goes up.

name: Jinteki big decision rush
description:
Cerebral overwriter or even just junebug could be the trap? maybe.

Hive is super taxing, 1 research is just a fourth econ for turn 1, you dont want to give them money often. Maybe 2 shi kyu could be fine. Fast track then mushin will probably be your turn once every game. Try not to play vs. silhouette ok
